item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“lardain, post:15, topic:550145”]Ah thanks, i never used that method before, therefore the strings, hehe. But thanks for the reply Sk8er. So what it actually does is int i = 0 would start at 0 and go up to 3. i++ would just keep adding untill the 3 has been reached right? So if i would put

for (int i = 100; i <= 200; i++){ system.out.printIn("Hello, i just spammed" +i "lines of text for you");// would probally give me a spam in the console like 100 101 to 200? }

But, this would be great to use to empty interfaces, for example a quest tab? Just get the child id`s and make it go from the first child to the last child ID of the strings?

PS: Thanks, you just learned me using loops within 10 seconds. :)[/quote]
Yes, this is actually a very, very common method that’s used to clear interfaces.
https://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,661108.0.html < In this snippet I actually do exactly what you said.

Read full topic

item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @lardain lardain
item.description:
@lardain wrote:

Ah thanks, i never used that method before, therefore the strings, hehe. But thanks for the reply Sk8er. So what it actually does is int i = 0 would start at 0 and go up to 3. i++ would just keep adding untill the 3 has been reached right? So if i would put

for (int i = 100; i <= 200; i++){ system.out.printIn("Hello, i just spammed" +i "lines of text for you");// would probally give me a spam in the console like 100 101 to 200? }

But, this would be great to use to empty interfaces, for example a quest tab? Just get the child id`s and make it go from the first child to the last child ID of the strings?

PS: Thanks, you just learned me using loops within 10 seconds.

Read full topic

item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

lardain:

I actually never used Loops, and when i see the difference I should use it. But what if I would like to make a command to set only the combat skills? Can`t i just use a list like private int skillToLevel[] = {"0", "1", "2", "3"}; Idk if this would work. I always make it myself harder than it is xD.

First, you’d want to make the values ints, and not strings.

Second, you probably wouldn’t need to make an array for combat levels since they’re the first few values (0-3)

for(int i = 0; i <= 3; i++) { System.out.println("Hello World" + i); }
Output:

Hello World0 Hello World1 Hello World2 Hello World3

Read full topic

item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

x rush x:

1. it is not a improper method, it is an inefficient method, 2. seriously you gonna reference wikipedia… good to know you know how google works

  1. Teach people the most efficient way of doing things.
    2.Wikipedia is a perfectly valid site for uncontroversial and common knowledge.

This is a terrible tutorial because you spend 90% teaching something else than what you’re supposed to do (Adding custom commands). It is safe to assume that people know Java when your tutorial is not about Java. If they don’t know how to use a for loop they can look it up.

And please use [code=java] and not just [code] in the future, it makes your code so much nicer to look at.

Read full topic

item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“x rush x, post:5, topic:550145”]repeating is good way of learning… it sinks in.
if you look at how i structured the tutorial its to detour people from copy paste, everything i wrote,
i want them to write it over and over so they will know what a variable is, what an array is, what a if statement is.[/quote]
Teaching them an improper method to do something is not something you want to sink in.

I understand you want to help people, but you need to think in the concept of DRY (Don’t Repeat Yourself).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

x rush x:

no… whats a loop!!!.. the tutorial is for beginners i left loops out to help focus on if statements, would have added it if i had more time

A beginners tutorial is the perfect time to show them what a for loop is, so they’re not repeatedly doing what you just posted.

Imagine them doing that for the friends list array (length: 100) Or how about a bank (length: usually > 400)

item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Hi, have you ever heard of the for loop?

I just trimmed your entire command down to this using one:

if (p.rights >= 2){ if (cmd[0].equals("master")) { for(int i = 0; i < p.skillLvl.length; i++) { p.skillLvl[i] = 99; p.skillXP[i] = 13034431; p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, i); } } }

Read full topic
item.source: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example

item.title: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
item.dc:creator: @x_rush_x x rush x
item.description:
@x_rush_x wrote:

Hey guys, so before we begin, i know this tutorial probably already exists but its not on the first page and well since
i was doing it myself anyways thought i would make a quick tutorial to help anyone else trying to do the same thing.

So this is based off 508 Palidino67 source, and instead of just saying do this do that i will explain the programming behind it at the same time
for any beginners wishing to know :).

Step 1:

Inside your server files you should have one called:
Commands.java

Now you are going to want to open this, i am using Notepad++ but you can use wtv you like.
Inside " Commands.java " you can make 3 different types of commands, well more but basics go >
if p.rights = 0 means if your normal player.
if p.rights = 1 means your a mod
if p.rights = 2 means your a admin or owner.

some servers use p.rights 3 for owner, you can also make your own rights for donators or what now,
but we will stick with the basic 3 for now just for the sake of time saving.

so inside " Commands.java " search for what level player you want to make the command for, norm, mod, admin and
you can do that by searching:

you will see something like this:
norm:
[spoiler]

 if (p.rights >= 0) {
                if (cmd[0].equals("male")) {
                    p.look[0] = 7; // Hair
                    p.look[1] = 16; // Beard
                    p.look[2] = 18; // Torso
                    p.look[3] = 28; // Arms
                    p.look[4] = 34; // Bracelets
                    p.look[5] = 38; // Legs
                    p.look[6] = 42; // Shoes
                    p.gender = 0;
                    p.appearanceUpdateReq = true;
                    p.updateReq = true;
                } else if (cmd[0].equals("female")) {
                    p.look[0] = 48; // Hair
                    p.look[1] = 1000; // Beard
                    p.look[2] = 57; // Torso
                    p.look[3] = 64; // Arms
                    p.look[4] = 68; // Bracelets
                    p.look[5] = 77; // Legs
                    p.look[6] = 80; // Shoes
                    p.gender = 1;
                    p.appearanceUpdateReq = true;
                    p.updateReq = true;
                } else if (cmd[0].equals("bank")) {
                    p.openBank();
                } else if (cmd[0].equals("item")) {
                    Engine.playerItems.addItem(p, Integer.parseInt(cmd[1]), Integer.parseInt(cmd[2]));
                }
            }

[/spoiler]
now right up at the top after:

is where we will add our command.

Now to understand what this line of code is: “SKIP IF YOU UNDERSTAND WHAT IF STATEMENTS ARE”
[spoiler]

what this is, in programming we have decisions making statements that are called " If statements ",
basically what it is saying in the line above is, if player rights are greater then or equal to 0, which is normal player.
then execute the next line of code, now at the end of this line, or right under it,
you will want a little " { " bracket like that, then space down a line and add " } " a bracket like that.
everything between these brackets is called a “CODE BLOCK” < btw dont add the quotations,
inside this code block is the command you want the program to execute.

as seen in the above code the statement is as such:

if (p.rights >= 0) {
                if (cmd[0].equals("male")) {

what this is called is a nested if statement,
inside the second line there, is the second if statement, but as you can see
the condition is different, the way it works is like this,

the second line of codes variables and condtion are:

this is an array, but it is a string array, and in java to compare and integer and to compare a string are done
to different ways,
integer:

string " instead of normal operators we will use .equals " :

what ever is in the (“YourCommandName”) is the command itself,
so lets say i was in game and that was my command name,
i would have to type ::YourCommandName

and that would execute what ever i put in the code block.

Basic if statement numeric operators are:
equal to:

greater then:

less then:

not equal to:

greater then or equal to:

less then or equal to:

and an if statement can have as many decissions as you want by using && or ||

&& means AND
|| means OR

so condtion AND condition both must be true.
condtion OR condtion, 1 or the other must be true.

ex:
if x is less then 4 and more then 2:

int x = 3;
if ( x < 4 && x > 2 )

ex 2:
if x is less then 4 or more then 2:

int x = 3;
if ( x < 4 || x > 2 )

[/spoiler]

Step 2:
Once you have determined what type of command you want to make, you begin.
for the sake of this tutorial i will be demonstrating the ::master command.
since i want only admins or up to be able to do it i will search for:

once you have found this then right after the { bracket you can start your if statement.

so for master i will put:

if(cmd[0].equals("master")){

then space down a line and add:

p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;

explaining what these lines mean: “SKIP IF YOU KNOW WHAT AN ARRAY IS”
[spoiler]
Ok so what p.skillLvl[0] = 99; is, is what we call an Array, it is a variable.
well its actually a variable variable, lol because p stands for player,
and is declared above that p = player :P.

when we declare a variable like lets say:

thats fine and dandy, but what if lets say, we have 25 skill levels…
it is very time consuming to write

int skillLvl; int skillLvl1; int skillLvl2; int skillLvl3; ect...

So wouldnt it be nice if we could declare all 25 of these variables in a single line?
yep.
well we can, by using what we call an ARRAY and how we do this is by adding the little box at the end []
leaving it without a number inside the box would make it infinite, but since we have a definitive amount " 25 "
we will put the 25 so it would like like this.

now i know your going wait, you said 25, how come you put 24, ha you messed up…
no…
see arrays start at 0 so when we put 24 we actually have 25 variables now.
we have

skillLvl[0] skillLvl[1] skillLvl[2] ect....
all the way to skillLvl[24], these variables are used with in the games programming to define, our 25 ingame skills.
im not going to get into which one is which but it goes in order, skillLvl[0] is atk, skillLvl[1] is str, and skillLvl[2] is def ect… or something like that. just play around and you will figure the order out.

so now what the = 99; is, well the = sign is your assignment operator assigning a value to each variable.
so here = is signing the value of 99 to the variable.
by default all skills are = to 1. but if a player lets say kills 100 goblins using attack, now his atk skill is = 4 lets say.

and the code below that line:

is the same thing but thats changing the experience. 13034431 is the amount of exp for lvl 99.

anyways i know i kept arrays short but thats just a quick definition of what they are.
[/spoiler]

step 3:
copy paste the crap out of it:

so now that we got

if(cmd[0].equals("master")){ p.skillLvl[0] = 99; p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;

we need to copy the

p.skillLvl[0] = 99; p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
and past it under itself 24 more times, to account for all 25 skills.

once you are done it should look like this.

p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;

And there you go, all done… NOT
the problem with this code is all the array variables are the same, so what you need to do now is
change the 0’s to different numbers like this:

p.skillLvl[0] = 99; p.skillXP[0] = 13034431; p.skillLvl[1] = 99; p.skillXP[1] = 13034431; p.skillLvl[2] = 99; p.skillXP[2] = 13034431; p.skillLvl[3] = 99; p.skillXP[3] = 13034431; p.skillLvl[4] = 99; p.skillXP[4] = 13034431; p.skillLvl[5] = 99; p.skillXP[5] = 13034431; ect...

all the way until you reach:

p.skillLvl[24] = 99;
p.skillXP[24] = 13034431;

once you are done that, then you should have something like this:

if (p.rights >= 2){
   if(cmd[0].equals("master")) {
            p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
            p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[1] = 99;
            p.skillXP[1] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[2] = 99;
            p.skillXP[2] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[3] = 99;
            p.skillXP[3] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[4] = 99;
            p.skillXP[4] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[5] = 99;
            p.skillXP[5] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[6] = 99;
            p.skillXP[6] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[7] = 99;
            p.skillXP[7] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[8] = 99;
            p.skillXP[8] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[9] = 99;
            p.skillXP[9] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[10] = 99;
            p.skillXP[10] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[11] = 99;
            p.skillXP[11] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[12] = 99;
            p.skillXP[12] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[13] = 99;
            p.skillXP[13] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[14] = 99;
            p.skillXP[14] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[15] = 99;
            p.skillXP[15] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[16] = 99;
            p.skillXP[16] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[17] = 99;
            p.skillXP[17] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[18] = 99;
            p.skillXP[18] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[19] = 99;
            p.skillXP[19] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[20] = 99;
            p.skillXP[20] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[21] = 99;
            p.skillXP[21] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[22] = 99;
            p.skillXP[22] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[23] = 99;
            p.skillXP[23] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[24] = 99;
            p.skillXP[24] = 13034431;

Now once your done that, you just need to add this code in that sets the frame to set your level:
add it in right under p.skillXP[24] = 13034431; maybe space down a line or 2.

p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 0);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 1);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 2);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 3);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 4);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 5);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 6);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 7);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 8);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 9);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 10);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 11);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 12);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 13);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 14);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 15);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 16);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 17);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 18);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 19);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 20);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 21);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 22);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 23);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 24);

now once you are done all that you just need to space down 1 more line, and close your code block with “}” bracket.

after doing all this you should have:
[spoiler]

if (p.rights >= 2){
if (cmd[0].equals("master")) {
            p.skillLvl[0] = 99;
            p.skillXP[0] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[1] = 99;
            p.skillXP[1] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[2] = 99;
            p.skillXP[2] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[3] = 99;
            p.skillXP[3] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[4] = 99;
            p.skillXP[4] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[5] = 99;
            p.skillXP[5] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[6] = 99;
            p.skillXP[6] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[7] = 99;
            p.skillXP[7] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[8] = 99;
            p.skillXP[8] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[9] = 99;
            p.skillXP[9] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[10] = 99;
            p.skillXP[10] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[11] = 99;
            p.skillXP[11] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[12] = 99;
            p.skillXP[12] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[13] = 99;
            p.skillXP[13] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[14] = 99;
            p.skillXP[14] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[15] = 99;
            p.skillXP[15] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[16] = 99;
            p.skillXP[16] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[17] = 99;
            p.skillXP[17] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[18] = 99;
            p.skillXP[18] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[19] = 99;
            p.skillXP[19] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[20] = 99;
            p.skillXP[20] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[21] = 99;
            p.skillXP[21] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[22] = 99;
            p.skillXP[22] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[23] = 99;
            p.skillXP[23] = 13034431;
            p.skillLvl[24] = 99;
            p.skillXP[24] = 13034431;

p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 0);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 1);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 2);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 3);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 4);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 5);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 6);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 7);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 8);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 9);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 10);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 11);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 12);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 13);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 14);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 15);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 16);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 17);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 18);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 19);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 20);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 21);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 22);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 23);
p.frames.setSkillLvl(p, 24);

}

Please now, i only put 1 closing bracket, because i am assuming you have more then 1 admin command, but every if statement,
needs a opening and closing bracket { }. so if you are working with a completely blank source and have no admin commands,
you need 2 " } " brackets at the end to close the if (p.rights = 2) { statement also.

[/spoiler]

I only used ::master as an example, but you can do it with anything really just get creative.
if you wanted to make a command to give you gold…

if(cmd[0].equals("gold"){
Engine.playerItems.addItem(p, ####, @@@@);  
}

would be the item id.

@@@@ is the amount of the item.

anyways, if you have any questions feel free to pm me, hope this help’s someone.

Read full topic
item.source: [508] Adding custom commands [TUT] - using master command example
